action.action-desc: Mr. Messer introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Financial Services

form.official-title: To amend the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 to authorize private parties to compel the Bureau to seek sanctions by filing civil actions, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Reigning In of Governmental Hostility To Sovereignty at the CFPB Act of 2017 or the RIGHTS at the CFPB Act of 2017.

section.header: Private parties authorized to compel the Bureau to seek sanctions by filing civil actions; Adjudications deemed actions
section.text: Section 1053 of the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 (12 U.S.C. 5563) is amended by adding at the end the following:

subsection.header: Private parties authorized To compel the Bureau To seek sanctions by filing civil actions

paragraph.text: In the case of any person who is a party to a proceeding brought by the Bureau under this section, to which chapter 5 of title 5, United States Code, applies, and against whom an order imposing a cease and desist order or a penalty may be issued at the conclusion of the proceeding, that person may, not later than 20 days after receiving notice of such proceeding, and at that personâ€™s discretion, require the Bureau to terminate the proceeding.
If a person requires the Bureau to terminate a proceeding pursuant to paragraph (1), the Bureau may bring a civil action against that person for the same remedy that might be imposed.

subsection.text: Any administrative adjudication commenced under this section shall be deemed an action for purposes of section 1054(g).
